content:
The project is already established enough that we have some tasks to complete (and which people are free to "claim" via replies to this thread), which I will divide into purely Lean tasks (formalizing something that has already been determined mathematically), Lean+math tasks (tasks that require doing some math and then formalizing it), and purely math tasks (solving a math problem, with the proof to be formalized later).

A. Purely Lean tasks:

  • A7-2. 7 equivalent to 2. Completed by @Edward van de Meent
  • A6-2. 6 equivalent to 2. Completed by @Edward van de Meent
  • A8. 8 does not imply 2,3,4,5,6, but 3,4,5,6 implies 8. (See the comment of @Aaron Hill below.)
  • A38-42. 38 is equivalent to 42. (See the comment of @Arend Mellendijk below.)
  • A41-46. 41 is equivalent to 46. Completed by @Leo Shine

B. Lean + math tasks:

  • B5. Establish a generating set of implications between 5 and the other equations in the graph as discussed below.
  • B387-42. 387 does not imply 42. Requires coming up with a suitable counterexample, and then verifying it. Completed by @Amir Livne Bar-on
  • B40. Establish a generating set of implications between 40 and the other equations in the graph as discussed below.
  • B43-387. 43 does not imply 387. Requires coming up with a suitable counterexample, and then verifying it. Completed by @Amir Livne Bar-on
  • B168. Establish a generating set of implications between 168 and the other equations in the graph discussed below. Claimed by @Bhavik Mehta

The tasks below are in reference to the current graph of dependencies:

C. Purely math tasks:

  • C3. Relating Equation 3 with the existing graph. Claimed by @Amir Livne Bar-on
  • C5. Relating Equation 5 with the existing graph. Completed by @Seraphina Nix
  • C6. Relating Equation 6 with the existing graph. Converted to A6-2
  • C7. Relating Equation 7 with the existing graph. Completed by @Edward van de Meent
  • C8. Relating Equation 8 with the existing graph. Claimed by @Aaron Hill
  • C38. Relating Equation 38 with the existing graph. Completed by @Arend Mellendijk
  • C39. Relating Equation 39 with the existing graph.
  • C40. Relating Equation 40 with the existing graph. Completed by @Seraphina Nix
  • C41. Relating Equation 41 with the existing graph. Completed by @Seraphina Nix
  • C168: Relating Equation 168 with the existing graph. Completed by @Bhavik Mehta

(By "relating", I mean declaring (e.g., in response to this thread) which existing equations imply, or are implied by, the equation in question.)

Finally, some more difficult and complex tasks that will be needed in order to scale the project up:

  • D1. A way to feed pairs of equations into an existing automated prover to collect implications and non-implications. Ideally, the output should already be in Lean, but even non-Lean output can be helpful, as it can be converted into formalization tasks of type A or type B.
  • D2. A way to automatically generate outstanding unsolved implications between existing equations, with a focus on the ones that are the least "redundant", or most "pivotal" in some sense.
  • D3. A way to automatically generate one or more visualizations of the progress thus far.
  • D4. Some API for Magma relations, allowing one to start proving metatheorems about relations (e.g., formalizing the observation that any relation of the form x = f(y,z,u) is equivalent to x=y.)

I will update this list as contributions come in. (For instance, if one of the "C" tasks is resolved, this will then create a number of "A" or "B" tasks.) Eventually I presume this sort of task management should be automated as the project scales up, but for the current size I believe I can handle it manually.
So I took at look at some of the equations and I have a question for you
Am I correct that you are okay with an instantiation of the Magma that is a group?
By definition this works. I just wonder if you are expecting a "stronger" proof. For example if I could give a semigroup or a monoid as a counterexample then maybe you don't want a group.
It looks like the two tasks in B are resolved: https://github.com/teorth/equational_theories/pull/6

Shreyas Srinivas said:

By definition this works. I just wonder if you are expecting a "stronger" proof. For example if I could give a semigroup or a monoid as a counterexample then maybe you don't want a group.

Yes, for this project any Magma will suffice for a counterexample, including those that are groups. One can of course try to "upgrade" counterexamples to have additional properties for aesthetic reasons, but this would be a matter of taste and would not directly impact the main goals of the project.
Hi! I'm claiming C3 too. Was working on it and didn't keep my Zulip open, if I got my Lean installation right I think I have it completed.
You can also open it in gitpod if you like that. Especially if there are any installation troubles.
I am just reviewing your B tasks PR

Thanks!

I'm not used to this mode of super-quick remote collaboration :sweat_smile:
I'd like to claim C6 (Equation 6)

Maybe we should add a task to integrate some existing equational solver? Then hopefully someone who ran a solver on the past can claim it, and otherwise there'll be more motivation to get started with one of the solvers
It's already there for solving equations. I added lean-egg as a dependency

Sounds like a good idea to add a task like this, but I'm not sure of the wording. Should I add a task to integrate any solver, or call out a specific one and ask for help in integrating it? I guess this can be done somewhat orthogonally to the Lean component, in that one can simply start feeding pairs of equations into a solver and recording the output in some file somewhere
This is a very non-trivial undertaking
Do check if you can use lean egg as described in the README here: https://github.com/marcusrossel/lean-egg

i don't have the time to formalize this, but it seems obvious for C7, equation 7 is equivalent to equation 2; when x = y * z, obviously x = y because x = x * x and y = x * x. the other way around is trivial.
yeah but where's commutativity
what commutativity? i didn't use it?
" x = y because x = x * x and y = x * x"
transitivity of equality?
for that you need x * x = y
specialize x = y * z with x:=y, y:=x, z:=x
yes that gives you y = x * x
sorry. This is probably a sign that I should sleep now.
Seems good to me. I'll mark C7 as completed and add a new task A7-2 to formalize the argument just stated.

Edward van de Meent said:

i don't have the time to formalize this, but it seems obvious for C7, equation 7 is equivalent to equation 2; when x = y * z, obviously x = y because x = x * x and y = x * x. the other way around is trivial.

In general, any equation of the form x = f(y, z, w) will be equivalent to x = y.

Thomas Browning said:

Edward van de Meent said:

i don't have the time to formalize this, but it seems obvious for C7, equation 7 is equivalent to equation 2; when x = y * z, obviously x = y because x = x * x and y = x * x. the other way around is trivial.

In general, any equation of the form x = f(y, z, w) will be equivalent to x = y.

Nice observation! I guess if we do formalize Magma words along the lines that @Adam Topaz has suggested then we can make this a general theorem, but for now we can do this on a case by case basis. But I think this covers C6 at least, so let me create a new task A6-2 for that.
Wow, eq6 is already gone :) I'd like to claim C8 (equation 8) instead
Wow, this is going much faster than I expected - so I'm adding four more equations (38-41) to the mix so that we don't run out of tasks.
I'd like to claim C168

A counterexample for Eq8: Eq8 does not imply eq2. If the elements are booleans with the operation x * y = x && y, then x = x && (x && x) (Eq8), but there is more than a single element (contradicting eq2)

Aaron Hill said:

A counterexample for Eq8: Eq8 does not imply eq2. If the elements are booleans with the operation x * y = x && y, then x = x && (x && x) (Eq8), but there is more than a single element (contradicting eq2)

Thanks! I've added a placeholder task A8-2 for this. But one might see if one can strengthen this claim by showing that A8 in fact does not imply some consequences of Eq2 (and in fact Eq2 is the strongest equation, in that every other equation is a consequence of Eq2).
i'd like to claim A6-2 and A7-2
A7-2 seems completed. That was fast

Is the intention at the moment to only work on the upstream equations? I pulled out equations of 1 variable and generated some brute force code to generate the simple implications from them, but I'm not sure if I should avoid adding new equations and this stage of the project is more for generating implies/not implies proofs to see what they look like and that will be scaled up some other way later. I can imagine that adding in a bunch of fairly trivial proofs would really slow checking down

At this stage it does not look like checking the Lean code is a bottleneck. Eventually we may split up the current Basic.lean file into many other files, some of which may be quite static and presumably can be precompiled. If you have achieved some automated way to generate some easy implications then that can certainly be added to the project (possibly under a different file, if you are worried about overwhelming the Basic.lean file) and we can figure out how best to integrate things later.
38 (xx = xy) seems equivalent to 42 (xy = xz) quite straightforwardly.

Submitted https://github.com/teorth/equational_theories/pull/12 Note that if A -> B -> C I avoided adding the proof for A -> C, I assume there is not yet a linter to check that the current code does not contain such unnecessary proofs? If not, I can take a look at writing one tomorrow
if people don't mind, i think it might be helpful if some docstrings are added for some of the simple equations....

C168: Equation 168 is not implied by either of 4 or 46 (the obvious magma on two elements in both cases works), and it does not imply any of equations 43, 3, 42 or 4512 (the natural central groupoid on a set of size 2 is a counterexample). This solves all edges between 168 and the existing nodes of the hasse diagram.
I'd like to claim B168 now :)
i'm not sure your first counterexample works? bool with or doesn't satisfy 4 nor 46, right?
oh oops, I misspoke, in both cases I mean the obvious construction on two elements for 4 and for 46 - edited

C5: I'd like to claim and solve Equation 5.

Equation 5 implies 3, 42, 4512. Each proof is via a simple series of applications to reduce an instance of y * x to x.

Equation 5 does not imply 43, 4513. In both cases, the magma with 2 elements a and b which satisfies equation 5 serves as a counterexample. For 43, a * b = b, but b * a = a. For 4513, a * (a * a) = a, but (a * a) * b = b. These non-implications are enough to resolve the rest of the graph (together with the nonimplication of 2, which is obvious).
It looks like 5 is the dual of 4, so 5 should also imply the dual of 4552, and by your argument, 4 doesn't imply the dual of 4513

Those both sound right to me - it doesn't seem the duals of 4552 or 4513 are in the project yet, but they could be natural ones to add since we have a fair amount of implications for free with duality.

It occurs to me that a tool for deriving implications via known implications and duality could be relatively self contained and might quickly become helpful as an extra bit of automation on top of the current tool for automating implications known via poset laws.

i seem to recall there is a mathlib tactic for at least the first part; adding in the duality relation might make it a bit more complicated, but it might be worth a look. i can't remember what it's called though...
i think it's solve_by_elim?
alternatively, we could try to leverage instance search?
The idea with instance search would be to create an instance that says something like A_dual -> B_dual gives A -> B and then hope that does most of the work?

C41: I will also claim and solve 41: it is equivalent to 46 (x*y=z*w). Essentially, x*x = y*z and x*x = u*w, so y*z = u*w. The reverse implication is by specialization.

More generally, much like the observation that x = f(y,z,u)is equivalent to x=y, there is a "metatheorem" that says x*y = f(u, v, w, z) is equivalent to x*y=z*w (46). And similar to the fact that x=y implies all laws, x*y=z*w implies all laws that have at least 1 * on each side of the equals, so only laws like 4 which have a bare variable on one side need to be placed relative to 46.
A similar logic applies to 4582 (x*(y*z)=(u*w)*v), but needs to be more nuanced for higher "depth" formulas; any equation with at least two multiplications is implied by this equation.

I suppose the great takeaway is that when f(x1,...,xn)=g(y1,...,ym), we can conclude f(x1,...,xn)=f(y1,...,yn), meaning it implies any formula where both sides of the equation are "f-shaped" (or "g-shaped"). For more complex f and g, i think this will no longer cover a cofinite subset of equations, meaning your conclusion of the argument becomes more nuanced

Suppose I'm able to bruteforce very simple implies and not-implies theorems, is there any minimization that can be done on the submitted theorems? For examples, with implies, if I have A->B->C and A->C, I don't have to include A->C, but transitivity doesn't hold for not-implies. I am asking because I am assuming that upstream would not want A->C in the case above, and more over it reduces the amount of brute forcing to eliminate looking at A->C if I already have A->B->C.

It should be very easy to write a Lean tactic that slurps in all the implications and disimplications from the Lean environment, computes their "closure", and tells you whether the current goal is already done.

Someone really really should write this before the project goes on too far!!
The same machinery should be hooked up to a linter that runs in CI and ensures the declarations are irredundant.

Some additional (non) implications involving equation 8:

  • Eq3 implies Eq8: Simplify x * (x * x) [Eq8] using x = x * x[Eq3] to obtain x
  • Eq8 does not imply Eq3: Use a two-element boolean magma with the operation x * y = x XOR y
  • Eq4 implies Eq8: Specialize x = x * y to x = x * x, and then simplify as in the Eq3 -> Eq8 case
  • Eq8 does not imply Eq4: Use a two-element boolean magma with the operation x * y = x XOR y
  • Eq5: Same as both eq4 cases, since x * y is just swapped to y * x
  • Eq6 implies Eq8: Specialize to x = x * x, then apply the Eq3 -> Eq8 implication
  • Eq8 does not imply Eq6: Use a two-element boolean magma with the operation x * y = x XOR y

I'll claim C40 x*x = y*y and say more about its placement within the poset in the near future. I'll also likely start looking at formalizing the C-tasks that I have been completing within LEAN and submitting a PR (or 3 PRs, probably); I think I can have at least one of the PRs out in <24h (but I also wouldn't mind if someone beat me to it c: ).

Ah, it took me a bit to notice, but I previously said I had finished task C5, but I had only given which implications are true and false among those implications of the form 5 -> X, not which are true and false among those implications of the form X -> 5.

Assuming the picture of the poset in the Github repo is complete, then the only law in the current poset which implies 3 is 4. Since 5 -> 3, if some law does not imply 3, it cannot imply 5 either. Thus, the only open one is does 4 -> 5? The answer is no by duality, since 5 -> 4 is false, and 5 and 4 are dual, 4 -> 5 is false. (the automated poset + duality checker would catch this in the future ).

I can place 40 (x*x = y*y) within the current poset. The implication relation it satisfies is 46->40 (by the previously discussed metatheorem, or by direct substitution. All the other possible implications (in either direction) are false, which we can show via a (minimal?) set of nonimplications:

The first 4 nonimplications are demonstrated by the "implies" magma with two elements, true and false, where "true implies false" is false and all other pairs are true. This shows that 40 does not imply 3, 42, 43, 4512.

4 does not imply 40 (4 is x = x*y). The 2 element magma that satisfies 4 does not satisfy 40.
387 does not imply 40 (387 is x*y = (y*y)*x). The "and" magma on the two element set of booleans satisfies 387, but does not satisfy 40.
4582 does not imply 40 (4582 is x*(y*z) = (w*u)*v). Here we need a magma that satisfies 4582, but isn't constant, since the constant law does imply 40; the first one I thought of is "saturating addition" on the set {1, 2, 3}, where we add in the normal way but cap the result at 3 (x*y = min(3, x+y)). And indeed this magma satisfies 4582 but not 40.

The other implications and non-implications with 40 can be filled in by the poset laws (and the ones between 40 and 5 can be filled in by duality, since 40 is self-dual). And the same counter-example that rules out 40->3, also rules out 40->8 (8->40 is ruled out by poset laws).

The graph of dependencies currently has an arrow from (5) to (38)/(42), which should be removed.
(39) (task C39) is dual to (38), and is therefore implied by (41)/(46) and (5) and implies (1).

I'm currently running a long-running process checking all combinations of equations where one implies the other just by rewriting (e.g. repeat intro; repeat rw [<-h]). Currently it's up to ~30k implications (including redundancies, e.g. where A->B->C and A->C). It should finish in ~20 hours.
About to create a Pull request for 41 equivalent to 46, I'm just doing it as 2 implications for now as no example of equivalence yet
Not sure if this is a bit pointless as this will be easily solved by various simple automated ideas but is here https://github.com/teorth/equational_theories/pull/20/files
I'll merge it if it passes CI
Is CI meant to be spending an hour rebuilding mathlib? Sounds expensive
It fetches the cache
Most of the build time is in the project

Floris van Doorn said:

The graph of dependencies currently has an arrow from (5) to (38)/(42), which should be removed.
(39) (task C39) is dual to (38), and is therefore implied by (41)/(46) and (5) and implies (1).

OK, I think I fixed it now. Certainly this Hasse graph is becoming unwieldy; I am thinking of maybe just adding a few more nodes - the duals of the equations we already have - but after that we should try to find a different way to organize the human proving portion of the project (I will create a separate thread about this). Related to this - can someone tell me what the equation numbers of the duals of the equations already present are? I unfortunately don't have the time to look them up right now.

After generating a bunch of refutations and simple proofs (via substitution and renaming), there are already 275 equations that have been "solved": it is known whether or not they imply every other equation. A further 73 have only one missing proof or contradiction. Here are a few of them

Equation2088[x = ((y ∘ x) ∘ x) ∘ (x ∘ y)] => Equation1223[x = x ∘ (((x ∘ x) ∘ x) ∘ x)]
Equation4155[x ∘ y = ((y ∘ x) ∘ x) ∘ y] => Equation4118[x ∘ y = ((x ∘ x) ∘ x) ∘ y]
Equation107[x = x ∘ ((y ∘ y) ∘ x)] => Equation411[x = x ∘ (x ∘ (x ∘ (x ∘ x)))]
Equation4268[x ∘ (x ∘ x) = x ∘ (x ∘ y)] => Equation4282[x ∘ (x ∘ y) = x ∘ (x ∘ z)]
Equation4269[x ∘ (x ∘ x) = x ∘ (y ∘ x)] => Equation4316[x ∘ (y ∘ x) = x ∘ (z ∘ x)]

If anyone is interested in trying to tackle some one-off proofs these might be fun; I can send you the remaining set.

Equation4268[x ∘ (x ∘ x) = x ∘ (x ∘ y)] => Equation4282[x ∘ (x ∘ y) = x ∘ (x ∘ z)]

  • rewrite using x:=x, y:=y to get x ∘ (x ∘ x) = x ∘ (x ∘ z) as goal, which is then exactly solved by specifying x:=x,y:=z
same method for Equation4269[x ∘ (x ∘ x) = x ∘ (y ∘ x)] => Equation4316[x ∘ (y ∘ x) = x ∘ (z ∘ x)]

Just a note that I have refactored Basic.lean into Magma.lean, Equations.lean, and Subgraph.lean, with the latter being devoted to the study of a small subgraph of the entire implications graph. All the other contributed implications should go into some separate lean file that imports from Equations.lean (which will need to be expanded to cover all 4694 equations rather than just the 20 or so that are being studied for Subgraph.lean). I have limited time right now so the refactoring may not have gone through properly, but hopefully any fixes are minor. In the meantime Basic.lean is deprecated and I will remove it later today, so if you were working on it please move to Subgraph.lean instead.

Also when I have time later this evening I will try to work with @Shreyas Srinivas on transitioning the outstanding tasks workflow to Github projects.

I am adding a series of workflows to automate the handling of tasks in the github project. When we announce the next version of tasks, I will explain the workflow. My goal is to incrementally improve the automation until we reach a point where we have a productive set of workflows that is easy for everyone to work with. There are boun to be hiccups initially. We welcome feedback from everyone. Hopefully we can converge on the correct defaults quickly

Nicholas Carlini said:

After generating a bunch of refutations and simple proofs (via substitution and renaming), there are already 275 equations that have been "solved": it is known whether or not they imply every other equation. A further 73 have only one missing proof or contradiction. Here are a few of them

Equation2088[x = ((y ∘ x) ∘ x) ∘ (x ∘ y)] => Equation1223[x = x ∘ (((x ∘ x) ∘ x) ∘ x)]
Equation4155[x ∘ y = ((y ∘ x) ∘ x) ∘ y] => Equation4118[x ∘ y = ((x ∘ x) ∘ x) ∘ y]
Equation107[x = x ∘ ((y ∘ y) ∘ x)] => Equation411[x = x ∘ (x ∘ (x ∘ (x ∘ x)))]

If anyone is interested in trying to tackle some one-off proofs these might be fun; I can send you the remaining set.

I feel like I have an approach to Eq 2088 does not => Eq 1223 which is make the carrier set for the magma the complex numbers then make the magma operation x ∘ y = a x + b y for some complex numbers.

You can then multiply out the equation for the RHS of 2088 which gives you something like a ^3 y + a ^2 b x + 2ab x + b^2 y and then you can choose a and b to make a^3 + b^2 = 0 and a ^2 b + 2 ab -1 = 0

Then if you let a = c^2 and b = i c^3 you set get a horrible polynomial like i c ^7 + 2i c^5 -1 = 0

and then you could use solutions to this as a magma for 2088 and I think it's quite unlikely that all of them will also make the magma rule for equation 1223 work, but I'm not that good at making few enough mistakes at algebra by hand to accurately check and don't really have experience with computer algebra packages to use them to check if this actually works

I mention this because I was able to get this approach to work when I'd misread Eq 2088 as[x = ((y ∘ x) ∘ (x ∘ y)] but the polynomials involved ended up being much simpler

Vlad Tsyrklevich said:

I'm currently running a long-running process checking all combinations of equations where one implies the other just by rewriting (e.g. repeat intro; repeat rw [<-h]). Currently it's up to ~30k implications (including redundancies, e.g. where A->B->C and A->C). It should finish in ~20 hours.

This finished with ~100k implications (with redundancies) and I'm running another simple brute force now. An interesting thing about having so many implications, is I was able to look for cycles in the graph (e.g. equivalent formulas), and found some, though not so many yet. The current list is:

[[4361, 4359], [3627, 3624], [3630, 3618], [3631, 3616], [3645, 3592], [3646, 3590], [3650, 3584], [3651, 3582], [4375, 4370], [4693, 4682], [3448, 3379], [4676, 4674], [4690, 4685], [3428, 3413], [3427, 3415], [3424, 3421], [3447, 3381], [4308, 4294], [4426, 4410], [353, 350], [4378, 4367], [3443, 3387], [4336, 4324], [4463, 4447], [356, 344], [3442, 3389], [4355, 4346], [4500, 4484], [4504, 4487], [4503, 4495], [357, 342], [4379, 4365, 4366, 4372, 4377, 4373], [4582, 4534, 4547, 4556, 4566, 4539, 4571], [4033, 3966], [4036, 4028], [4037, 3969], [4051, 4015], [4052, 3977], [4056, 4011], [4057, 3981], [4236, 4169], [4239, 4231], [4240, 4172], [4254, 4218], [4255, 4180], [4259, 4214], [4260, 4184], [4623, 4609], [405, 389], [4651, 4639], [408, 400], [4670, 4661], [409, 392], [4694, 4680, 4681, 4687, 4692, 4688], [46, 44]]

I figure eventually we'll want to pull cycles like these out and group them together when trying to graph relationships to reduce clutter.
Is your set of 100k a superset of my 50k from (https://github.com/teorth/equational_theories/pull/23)? If so I will just close my issue.

I haven't had a chance to take a look yet. I'm still exploring. My generation code is also awful, and to upstream proofs I should also have a generator script that is worth upstreaming too. I haven't gotten to figuring that out yet. It would be nice to have a simple function that would allow bruteforcing arbitrary statements in lean itself--my skill at lean is lacking though
Terence Tao has marked this topic as resolved.
